Gonzalo Otamendi''' ({{IPA-es|nikoˈlas otaˈmendi}}; born 12 February 1988) is an Argentine professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Defender (association football)#Centre-back|centre back]] for {{English football updater|ManchesC}} club [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] and the [[Argentina national football team|Argentine national team]].
He played for [[Club Atlético Vélez Sarsfield|Vélez Sarsfield]] and [[FC Porto|Porto]] in his early career, winning eight major titles with the latter including three [[Primeira Liga]] championships and the [[2011 UEFA Europa League Final|2011 Europa League]]. He signed for Manchester City in 2015 from [[Valencia CF|Valencia]] (with the latter club also loaning him to [[Clube Atlético Mineiro|Atlético Mineiro]] of Brazil for four months), winning the [[Premier League]] in [[2017–18 Premier League|2017–18]] as well as three [[EFL Cup|League Cups]].
An [[Argentina national football team|Argentina international]] since 2009, Otamendi represented his country at two [[FIFA World Cup|World Cups]] and as many [[Copa América|Copas América]], in which he contributed to consecutive runner-up finishes.
==Club career== ===Vélez=== Born in [[Buenos Aires]], Otamendi made his [[Argentine Primera División|Primera División]] debut for [[Club Atlético Vélez Sarsfield]] on 10 May 2008, in a 2–1 home win against [[Rosario Central]] for the [[2007–08 Argentine Primera División#Torneo Clausura|Clausura tournament]].<ref name=Nacion>{{cite news|url=http://www.lanacion.com.ar/nota.asp?nota_id=1122686|title=Nicolás Otamendi: "El de Vélez es un grupo con hambre"|trans-title=Nicolás Otamendi: "Vélez is a hungry group"|newspaper=[[La Nación]]|language=Spanish|date=28 April 2009|accessdate=2 October 2009}}</ref> During manager [[Hugo Tocalli]]'s spell he was only fifth-choice stopper, behind [[Waldo Ponce]], [[Fernando Tobio]], [[Marco Torsiglieri]] and [[Mariano Uglessich]]. However, his role in the first team changed during [[Ricardo Gareca]]'s first season as head coach, the [[2008–09 Argentine Primera División#Torneo Clausura|2009 Clausura]]: he replaced Ponce for the third game after the [[Chile]]an was injured while playing for [[Chile national football team|his national team]],<ref name=Nacion/> and eventually won a starting position alongside [[Sebastián Domínguez]],<ref name=Nacion/> playing 17 of the 19 games in Vélez's winning campaign.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.argentinesoccer.com/player_apps.cfm?id=otmd&Championship=cl09&Team=vel|title=Closing '09 statistics|publisher=Argentine Soccer|accessdate=8 August 2010}}</ref>
Otamendi scored his first professional goal during the [[2009–10 Argentine Primera División#Torneo Apertura|2009 Apertura]], in a 3–1 victory over [[Arsenal de Sarandí]]. During that season he also made his debuts in an international club competition, [[2009 Copa Sudamericana|appearing]] in the [[Copa Sudamericana]]; in recognition of his performances throughout the year he was chosen for the ''South American Team of the Year'', in a traditional continent-wide journalists' poll conducted by the newspaper ''[[El País (Montevideo)|El País]]''.<ref name=SATY>{{cite web|url=http://www.24con.com/conurbano/nota/33849-Ver%C3%B3n-fue-elegido-como-el-mejor-jugador-de-Am%C3%A9rica/|title=Verón fue elegido como el mejor jugador de América|trans-title=Verón chosen best player in America|publisher=24CON|language=Spanish|date=31 December 2009|accessdate=31 December 2009}}</ref>
===Porto=== On 23 August 2010, Otamendi was transferred to Portuguese side [[FC Porto]] on a €4 million fee, signing a five-year contract.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.uefa.com/uefaeuropaleague/news/newsid=1517284.html|title=Porto sign Argentina defender Otamendi|publisher=UEFA|date=23 August 2010|accessdate=25 August 2010}}</ref> Vélez also retained 50% of his registration rights, with the player having a pre-set price of another €4 million to be met by Porto prior to September 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fcporto.pt/IncFCP/PDF/Investor_Relations/FactosRelevantes/CompraOtamendi23082010.pdf|title=Acordo de princípio para a compra do jogador Otamendi|trans-title=Negotiations for acquisition of player Otamendi|publisher=FC Porto|language=Portuguese|date=23 August 2010|accessdate=29 August 2010|format=PDF|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110930101322/http://www.fcporto.pt/IncFCP/PDF/Investor_Relations/FactosRelevantes/CompraOtamendi23082010.pdf|archivedate=30 September 2011}}</ref> He netted in his first match, a 2–0 home victory over [[S.C. Olhanense]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.portugoal.net/index.php/more-liga-sagres-news/16655-can-anybody-stop-this-dragon|title=Can anybody stop this Dragon?|publisher=PortuGOAL|date=26 September 2010|accessdate=9 November 2012}}</ref> finishing [[2010–11 Primeira Liga|his first season]] with 15 appearances and five goals (notably both in a 2–0 away win against [[S.C. Braga]])<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.portugoal.net/index.php/more-liga-sagres-news/21069-no-let-up-from-fc-porto-and-benfica|title=No let-up from FC Porto and Benfica|publisher=PortuGOAL|date=14 February 2011|accessdate=9 November 2012}}</ref> as the [[Porto|northerners]] won the [[Primeira Liga]] championship.
On 6 September 2011, Porto exercised the rights to sign the remainder of Otamendi's playing rights.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.fifa.com/worldfootball/clubfootball/news/newsid=1505819.html|title=Porto finalise Otamendi purchase|publisher=FIFA|date=6 September 2011|accessdate=9 November 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fcporto.pt/IncFCP/PDF/Investor_Relations/FactosRelevantes/Compra50Otamendi_06092011.pdf|title=Comunicado|trans-title=Announcement|publisher=FC Porto|language=Portuguese|date=6 September 2011|accessdate=20 September 2011}}</ref> He played 30 official games during [[2011–12 Primeira Liga|the season]] to help the club to another two major titles, notably the back-to-back domestic league.
===Valencia=== [[File:Nicolás Otamendi 2015 (cropped).jpg|thumb|upright|Otamendi with Valencia in 2015]] On 5 February 2014, Otamendi was sold to [[Valencia CF]] in [[La Liga]] for €12 million, on a five-year contract starting on 1 July.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.insidespanishfootball.com/97018/valencia-confirm-signing-of-nicolas-otamendi/|title=Valencia confirm signing of Nicolás Otamendi|publisher=Inside Spanish Football|date=5 February 2014|accessdate=6 February 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140206011550/http://www.insidespanishfootball.com/97018/valencia-confirm-signing-of-nicolas-otamendi/|archivedate=6 February 2014}}</ref> He was immediately loaned to [[Clube Atlético Mineiro]] in [[Brazil]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.goal.com/es/news/21/fichajes/2014/02/07/4603034/nicolas-otamendi-jugar%C3%A1-en-atl%C3%A9tico-mineiro-cedido-por-el|title=Nicolas Otamendi jugará en Atlético Mineiro cedido por el Valencia|trans-title=Nicolas Otamendi will play in Atlético Mineiro loaned by Valencia|publisher=[[Goal (website)|Goal]]|language=Spanish|date=7 February 2014|accessdate=14 February 2014}}</ref> and played 19 times for the team from [[Belo Horizonte]], scoring once to open a 4–1 win at city rivals [[América Futebol Clube (MG)]] on 23 March in the first leg of the semi-finals of the [[Campeonato Mineiro|state championship]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.atletico.com.br/atletico-goleia-o-america-e-larga-na-frente-na-semifinal-do-mineiro/|title=Atlético goleia o América e larga na frente na semifinal do Mineiro|trans-title=Atlético thrash América and lead the ''Mineiro'' semi-final|publisher=Atlético Mineiro|language=Portuguese|date=23 March 2014|accessdate=13 June 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://en.valenciacf.com/ver/36643/nicolas-otamendi.html?temporada=2014|title=Nicolás Otamendi|publisher=Valencia CF|accessdate=20 June 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150321053608/http://en.valenciacf.com/ver/36643/nicolas-otamendi.html?temporada=2014|archivedate=21 March 2015}}</ref>
Otamendi made his debut in the [[Spanish football league system|Spanish top level]] on 23 August 2014, starting in a 1–1 away draw against [[Sevilla FC]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.marca.com/eventos/marcador/futbol/2014_15/primera/jornada_1/sev_val/|title=Punto de fe del Valencia|trans-title=Valencia point of faith|newspaper=[[Marca (newspaper)|Marca]]|last=Campos|first=Tomás|language=Spanish|date=23 August 2014|accessdate=3 September 2014}}</ref> He scored his first goal for his new club on 4 October, helping to a 3–1 home success over [[Atlético Madrid]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.superdeporte.es/valencia/2014/10/02/valencia-atletico-madrid-partido-directo-tv-online/236350.html|title=El Valencia derroca al campeón de Liga|trans-title=Valencia knock League champions out|newspaper=[[Super Deporte]]|last=Bengoa|first=Javier|language=Spanish|date=4 October 2014|accessdate=4 October 2014}}</ref>
On 4 January 2015, Otamendi headed Valencia's winner in a 2–1 home win over [[Real Madrid C.F.|Real Madrid]], ending their opponents' club record 22-match winning streak as a result.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/30673410|title=Valencia 2–1 Real Madrid|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|last=Oliver|first=Pete|date=4 January 2015|accessdate=4 January 2015}}</ref> After helping ''Los Che'' [[2015–16 UEFA Champions League|qualify]] for the [[UEFA Champions League]] for the first time in four years, becoming the first club stopper to score six goals in the league in the process,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://valencia.eldesmarque.com/valencia-cf/noticias/4369-historico-otakaiser-primer-central-che-que-marca-seis-goles-en-liga|title=Histórico 'Otakaiser': primer central che que marca seis goles en Liga|trans-title=Historical 'Otakaiser': first ''che'' stopper who scores six goals in League|publisher=El Desmarque|last=Gimeno|first=Manu|language=Spanish|date=23 May 2015|accessdate=8 September 2015}}</ref> he was the only player from his team to be named in the La Liga Team of the Year.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-3126163/Lionel-Messi-Cristiano-Ronaldo-lead-La-Liga-team-year-Gareth-Bale-misses-out.html|title=Cristiano Ronaldo and Lionel Messi lead La Liga team of the year... but there's no place for Gareth Bale after disappointing season|newspaper=[[Daily Mail]]|last=Skinner|first=Adam|date=17 June 2015|accessdate=24 June 2015}}</ref>
===Manchester City=== Late into the 2015 pre-season, Otamendi refused to train or play with Valencia to avoid thwarting his chances of signing with another club.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.mundodeportivo.com/futbol/valencia/20150814/201242126032/otamendi-se-niega-a-jugar-con-el-valencia.html|title=Otamendi se niega a jugar con el Valencia|trans-title=Otamendi refuses to play with Valencia|newspaper=[[Mundo Deportivo]]|language=Spanish|date=15 August 2015|accessdate=8 September 2015}}</ref> On 20 August, he joined [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] on a five-year deal for an initial fee of £28.5 million.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mcfc.com/News/Team-news/2015/August/Manchester-City-sign-Nicolas-Otamendi-from-Valencia/1439913882|title=Nicolas Otamendi joins City|publisher=Manchester City F.C|date=20 August 2015|accessdate=20 August 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/34002463|title=Nicolas Otamendi: Manchester City sign £32m Argentina defender|publisher=BBC Sport|date=20 August 2015|accessdate=20 August 2015}}</ref> He made his debut on 15 September, coming on as a 75th-minute [[Substitute (association football)|substitute]] for [[Vincent Kompany]] in a 1–2 home loss against [[Juventus F.C.]] for the [[2015–16 UEFA Champions League|Champions League]] [[2015–16 UEFA Champions League group stage|group phase]];<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.uefa.com/uefachampionsleague/season=2016/matches/round=2000634/match=2015671/postmatch/report/index.html|title=Morata earns Juventus victory at Manchester City|publisher=UEFA.com|date=15 September 2015|accessdate=15 September 2015}}</ref> his [[Premier League]] debut came four days later, in a 1–2 defeat to [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] at the [[City of Manchester Stadium]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/34191909|title=Manchester City 1–2 West Ham United|publisher=BBC Sport|last=Jurejko|first=Jonathan|date=19 September 2015|accessdate=1 November 2015}}</ref>
On 31 October 2015, Otamendi scored his first goal for the club in a 2–1 home win over [[Norwich City F.C.|Norwich City]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/34623887|title=Manchester City 2–1 Norwich City|publisher=BBC Sport|last=Osborne|first=Chris|date=31 October 2015|accessdate=1 November 2015}}</ref> He played the full 120 minutes as they [[2015–16 Football League Cup|won]] the [[Football League Cup]] on 28 February 2016, defeating [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] on a [[Penalty shoot-out (association football)|penalty shootout]] in [[2016 Football League Cup Final|the final]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/35624164|title=Liverpool 1–1 Manchester City|publisher=BBC Sport|last=McNulty|first=Phil|date=28 February 2016|accessdate=13 June 2016}}</ref>
==International career== [[File:Nicolás Otamendi.jpg|thumbnail|Otamendi playing for [[Argentina national football team|Argentina]] in 2009]] In April 2009, Otamendi was called up by [[Argentina national football team|Argentine national team]] coach [[Diego Maradona]] for a [[Exhibition game|friendly]] with [[Panama national football team|Panama]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ole.clarin.com/notas/2009/04/17/seleccion/01899938.html|title=Bocación local|trans-title=Local bocation|newspaper=[[Olé (sports newspaper)|Olé]]|last=Sottile|first=Marcelo|language=Spanish|date=17 April 2009|accessdate=2 October 2009}}</ref> At the time of his selection he had only played 11 professional games,<ref name=Nacion/> and eventually started the match on 20 May, in a 3–1 win.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.lanacion.com.ar/1130238-con-destellos-la-argentina-vencio-a-panama-3-a-1|title=Con destellos, la Argentina venció a Panamá 3 a 1|trans-title=With flashes, Argentina beat Panama 3 to 1|newspaper=La Nación|language=Spanish|date=20 May 2009|accessdate=24 November 2018}}</ref>
During the [[2010 FIFA World Cup]] [[2010 FIFA World Cup qualification (CONMEBOL)|qualifying campaign]], Otamendi played as a centre back alongside [[Martín Demichelis]] against [[Ecuador national football team|Ecuador]] (0–2 away loss), partnered former Vélez teammate Domínguez against [[Brazil national football team|Brazil]] in a 1–3 home defeat and appeared as a right back in a 1–0 win in [[Uruguay national football team|Uruguay]] which sealed the country's qualification to South Africa.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lacapitalmdp.com/noticias/Deportes/2009/10/11/123504.htm|title=Maradona probó con Otamendi como lateral|trans-title=Maradona tested Otamendi as fullback|publisher=La Capital MdP|language=Spanish|date=11 October 2009|accessdate=8 September 2015}}</ref> On 19 May 2010 he was confirmed as part of the 23-men squad for the final stages,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ole.com.ar/mundial/argentina/Maradona_0_264573643.html|title=¡Acá están, estos son!|trans-title=These are the guys!|newspaper=Olé|language=Spanish|date=19 May 2010|accessdate=19 May 2010}}</ref> featuring in the starting eleven for the [[2010 FIFA World Cup Group B#Greece vs Argentina|final group stage game]] against [[Greece national football team|Greece]]; on the press conference after the match, Maradona said that, in his opinion, he was the best player on the field.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ole.com.ar/mundial/argentina/Liniers-queda-Sudafrica_0_285571449.html|title=Liniers queda en Sudáfrica|trans-title=Liniers stays in South Africa|newspaper=Olé|language=Spanish|date=23 June 2010|accessdate=23 June 2010}}</ref>
Otamendi also played the 90 minutes of the [[2010 FIFA World Cup knockout stage#Argentina vs Mexico|round-of-16 game]] against [[Mexico national football team|Mexico]], which Argentina won by 3–1. His final appearance in the tournament was the 0–4 [[2010 FIFA World Cup knockout stage#Argentina vs Germany|quarter-final]] loss to [[Germany national football team|Germany]]: this time his performance received criticism by the football press, as did his manager's decision to improvise him on the right-back position;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.goal.com/en-gb/news/2890/world-cup-2010/2010/07/04/2009766/world-cup-2010-comment-javier-zanetti-or-nicolas-otamendi|title=World Cup 2010 Comment: Javier Zanetti or Nicolas Otamendi? The decision to snub Inter's captain cost Maradona & Argentina|publisher=Goal|last=Edwards|first=Daniel|date=4 July 2010|accessdate=16 July 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/worldcup2010/article-1291953/WORLD-CUP-2010-Diego-Maradona-finally-exposed-Argentinas-weakest-link--right-back.html|title=Diego Maradona finally exposed as Argentina's weakest link... along with their right full back|newspaper=[[Daily Mail]]|last=Ladyman|first=Ian|date=5 July 2010|accessdate=16 July 2010}}</ref> however, the player subsequently stated his desire to always play for his national team, even if not in his natural position.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ole.com.ar/seleccion/Quiero-jugar-siempre-posicion_0_299370177.html|title=Quiero jugar siempre aunque no sea en mi puesto|trans-title=I want to play always even if it's out of position|newspaper=Olé|language=Spanish|date=16 July 2010|accessdate=16 July 2010}}</ref>
Otamendi scored his first goal for Argentina on 2 September 2011, in a 1–0 friendly win over [[Venezuela national football team|Venezuela]] in [[Kolkata]], after heading a [[Corner kick|corner]] taken by [[Lionel Messi]].<ref name="goal1">{{cite news|url=http://www.elcomercio.com/deportes/futbol/Argentina-Sabella-comienza-Venezuela-Calcuta_0_547145327.html|title=La Argentina de Sabella comienza con victoria ante Venezuela en Calcuta|trans-title=Sabella's Argentina start with win against Venezuela in Kolkata|newspaper=El Comercio|language=Spanish|date=2 September 2011|accessdate=1 February 2014}}</ref> After being cut from the squad that later appeared at the [[2014 FIFA World Cup|2014 World Cup]],<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.fifa.com/world-match-centre/news/newsid/248/732/7/|title=Otamendi making the most of every opportunity|publisher=FIFA|date=3 December 2014|accessdate=14 June 2015}}</ref> he was selected by coach [[Gerardo Martino]] for the [[2015 Copa América]],<ref>{{cite news|url=http://canchallena.lanacion.com.ar/1796405-gerardo-martino-confirmo-la-lista-de-23-convocados-y-mantuvo-a-casco-para-la-copa-america|title=Gerardo Martino confirmó la lista de 23 convocados y mantuvo a Casco para la Copa América|trans-title=Gerardo Martino confirmed list of 23 selected and kept Casco for the Copa América|newspaper=La Nación|language=Spanish|date=27 May 2015|accessdate=27 May 2015}}</ref> playing the entirety of all but one match as they lost to hosts [[Chile national football team|Chile]] on a penalty shootout in [[2015 Copa América Final|the final]]; he was named in the Team of the Tournament.<ref name=TOTT>{{cite web|url=http://www.ca2015.com/en/gallery/copa-america-2015---team-of-the-tournament/1nqqmzngdosa911z9l2g8k8317/slide/13|title=Copa América 2015 – Team of the tournament|publisher=[[CONMEBOL]]|date=5 July 2015|accessdate=5 July 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150707200522/http://www.ca2015.com/en/gallery/copa-america-2015---team-of-the-tournament/1nqqmzngdosa911z9l2g8k8317/slide/13|archivedate= 7 July 2015|df=}}</ref>
Otamendi started all the games in the [[Copa América Centenario]] in the United States, in which Argentina again both faced Chile in the tournament final and lost in a penalty shootout, [[Copa América Centenario Final|2–4]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/jun/26/chile-win-copa-america-argentina-match-report-penalty-shoot-out|title=Chile win Copa América once again as Argentina title drought continues|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|last=Timms|first=Aaron|date=27 June 2016|accessdate=27 June 2016}}</ref> In the second group match against [[Panama national football team|Panama]], on 10 June 2016, he scored the opening goal in a 5–0 win.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/jun/10/lionel-messi-hat-trick-argentina-panama-copa-america|title=Lionel Messi scores brilliant hat-trick as Argentina surge into quarter-finals|newspaper=The Guardian|date=11 June 2016|accessdate=11 June 2016}}</ref>
Otamendi was included in the squad for the [[2018 FIFA World Cup|2018 World Cup]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/44203700|title=World Cup 2018: Messi and Aguero in Argentina squad but Icardi out|publisher=BBC Sport|date=21 May 2018|accessdate=23 May 2018}}</ref>
